Three coordination polymers based on the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), namely [Zn(L)0.5-(2,2′-bpy)]n(1), [Ni2(2,2′-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]L·3H2O (2) and [Cd(L)(1,10-phen)] (3) [L = oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)], (2,2′-bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine), (1,10-phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction: compound 1 is one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting in extensive hydrogen bonds built with the help of lattice water molecules, compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds were also characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis; furthermore, the magnetic measurements for 2 reveal antiferromagnetic coupling between the nickel(II) ions.

Introduction

Metal organic coordination networks have attracted a great deal of interest in recent years because of fundamental scientific interest and their potential applications in catalysis, absorption, magnetism and luminescence [1, 2]. The construction of MOFs mainly depends on the nature of the organic ligands (spacers) and metal ions (nodes) [3–5]. Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for a large diversity of topologies [6], but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures [7, 8]. On the other hand, the coordinating properties of N,N′-bis(coordinating group substituted) oxamides have been thoroughly investigated both in aqueous solution and in the solid state. The easy cis–trans isomerization equilibria that they exhibit together with the great variety of N,N′-substituents which can be used to play on the overall charge, complexing ability and polarity, make them very suitable ligands in designing homo- and heterometallic species [9–11]. Finally, one of the most appealing aspects of this type of ligands is the remarkable efficiency they exhibit to mediate strong antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers when acting as bridges [12, 13].

In this regard, numerous substituents have been used to produce different kinds of oxamides, but to the best of our knowledge, we are the first to use 4-amino phthalic acid to synthesize such a ligand, namely oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). This ligand possess four carboxylic groups which can feature various coordination modes (Scheme 1) therefore leading to a variety of metal organic frameworks.

In the present work, we report the synthesis of three coordination polymers by the use of different metal cations, oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid) and two auxiliary ligands: 2,2-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline. The 2,2-bipyridine chelates to metal ions through both of its nitrogen atoms and acts as a terminal or capping ligand. Therefore, hybrid structures containing 2,2-bipyridine are typically of lower dimensionalities [14], and as it is expected when using 2,2-bipyridine as an auxiliary ligand, we obtained two complexes with low dimensionalities [Zn(L)0.5(2,2′-bpy)]n(1) and [[Ni2(2,2′-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-L·3H2O (2); complex 1 is one-dimensional while complex 2 is zero dimensional, but with the help of hydrogen bonds created by lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated ligand, a three-dimensional framework was built. 1,10-phenanthroline as an auxiliary ligand has strong chelating ability and good π-conjugated character because of the disposition of nitrogen atoms within the fused aromatic system which makes 1,10-phenanthroline a nearly universal ligand for d- and f-block metals [15–19]. Using 1,10-phenanthroline, complex 3 [Cd(L)(1,10-phen) which is three dimensional, was constructed.

Experimental sectionGeneral physical measurements

X-ray crystallography data for 1–3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, O) were recorded on a VxRio EL Instrument. IR spectra were recorded in the 4000–400 cm−1 range as KBr pellets on an FTS 3000 (US digilab) spectrometer (fig. S1–S4).

Materials and general methods

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)(obpha) H4L was prepared in an analogous way to that reported for oxamide bis(2-benzoic) acid (H4obbz) [12] with slight modification (Scheme 2); 1.3 g (0.01 mol) of oxalyl chloride was added dropwise to a solution of 3.0 g (0.022 mol) of 4-aminophthalic acid in 50 mL of THF, and the mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 5 h. H4L precipitated as a white solid and was filtered off, washed with THF and dried. The yield was 75 %.

Synthesis of complex [Zn<sub>2</sub>(<italic>L</italic>)(2,2′-bpy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (0.047 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 140 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature; colorless needle-like crystals of 1 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 70 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3306 (w), 3061 (w), 1701 (s), 1605 (s), 1472 (m), 1433 (m), 1373 (s), 1154 (w), 1024 (w), 834 (w), 778 (m), 589 (w), 533 (w), 457 (w), 417 (w) fig (S2).

Synthesis of complex [Ni<sub>2</sub>(2,2′-bpy)<sub>4</sub>(<italic>µ</italic><sup>2</sup>-Ox)]-<italic>L</italic>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (2)

A mixture of NiSO4·7H2O (0; 056 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 110 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Violet block crystals of 2 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 63 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3843 (w), 3741 (w), 3422 (s), 1642 (s), 1596 (w), 1506 (s), 1441 (w), 1351 (m), 1235 (w), 1153 (w), 1063 (w), 1024 (w), 925 (w), 826 (w), 770 (s), 417 (w) fig (S3).

Synthesis of complex [Cd(<italic>L</italic>)(1,10-phen)] (3)

A mixture of CdSO4·2H2O (0.049 g 0.2 mmol), L (042 g, 0.1 mmol), 1,10-phen (0.072 g, 0.4 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 130 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 3 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 55 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3461 (s), 1636 (m), 1382 (w), 1114 (w), 1072 (w), 860 (w), 770 (w), 671 (w), 572 (w) fig (S4).

X-ray crystallography

X-ray crystallography data for 1–3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles for 1–3 are supplied in Tables 2 and 3.

Results and discussionStructure description of <bold>1</bold>

X-ray structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P – 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of one half oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), one 2,2′-bpy ligand and one crystallographically unique Zn(II) ion. The Zn(II) center is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two H4L anions and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2-bpy ligand showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Fig. 1a). The average Zn–O and Zn–N distances are 2.46 and 2.064 Å, respectively. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances are quite similar to the normal Zn–O and Zn–N distances [20, 21]. The metal ions bind the oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups leaving the oxygens in the amido groups uncoordinated. Each H4L anion connects four Zn(II) cations and each two Zn(II) cations are connected by two H4L ligands to form a ladder-like one-dimensional chain with the metal ions and 2,2′-bpy at the edges of the chain (Fig. 1b). The 2,2′-bpy ligands and the H4L occupy two planes perpendicular to each other (Fig. 1c).

Structure description of [Ni<sub>2</sub>(2,2′-bpy)<sub>4</sub>(<italic>µ</italic><sup>2</sup>-Ox)]-(<italic>L</italic>)·3H<sub>2</sub>O (2)

X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P − 1(2), and the asymmetric unit consists of one H4L which is uncoordinated with the nickel ions, four units of 2,2′-bpy ligand, one oxalate anion, three lattice water molecules and two Ni(II) ions (Fig. 2b). The Ni(II) ions adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, and each Ni(II) is connected by two oxalato oxygen atoms from one µ2-oxalato anion and four nitrogen atoms from two 2,2′-bpy, one of which occupies the axial position and the other occupies the equatorial position.

The architecture constructed by the Ni-bpy-oxalato moieties is extended through multiple hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional metal organic framework in which the molecules of water situated within the framework and stabilizing it by hydrogen-bonding interactions play a significant role beside the uncoordinated H4L ligand in connecting the different molecules of the complex (Fig. 2c); all water molecules are µ3-bonded: O10W–O1 = 2.77 Å, O10W–O7 = 11.01 Å, O10W–O8W = 10.44 Å, O8W–O5 = 3.302 Å, O8W–O9W = 2.843 Å, O9W–O4 = 2.802 Å, O9W–O3 = 2.791 Å; in addition to hydrogen bonds formed by water molecules, the molecular structure features intramolecular hydrogen bonds between O2 and O3, O2–O3 = 2.398 Å.

It is worth noting that oxalate anions were formed as a result of amide bond cleavage in some H4L ligands, and these anions tend to connect two nickel ions (Ni–Ni = 5.41 Å) by chelating mode leading to construction of a binuclear cluster supported by four bpy ligands (Fig. 2a).

Structure description of <bold>3</bold>

The X-ray structural determination indicates that complex 3 is a three-dimensional complex which crystallizes in monoclinic space group P 1 21/n 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of a Cd(II) ion, four oxygen atoms from three different H4L and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10 phenanthroline leading to an octahedral geometry around the central metal as illustrated in (Fig. 3a). The H4L anions show two types of coordination modes: the first anion has one bonding carboxylate group which is chelating bis-bidentate with a Cd–Cd distance of 15.432 Å and the other one connects four Cd(II) metal centers in a monodentate fashion which finally forms two-dimensional layers (Fig. 3b); these layers are connected by the bis-bidentate carboxylato groups to construct the three-dimensional layer (Fig. 3c).

Extensive intramolecular hydrogen bonds were observed among the oxamido groups and the carboxylato groups within H4L ligand [N(2)–O(7) = 2.916 Å; N(1)–O(5) = 2.675 Å; N(1)–O(10) = 3.046 Å], also hydrogen bonds were observed between oxygens in carboxylato groups O(8)–O(9) = 2.445 Å; O(3)–O(1) = 2.364 Å; O(3)–O(9) = 3.024 Å.

PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out to check the purity of 1–3. The observed PXRD patterns are in good accordance with those simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. 4) and indicated the phase purity of the as-synthesized products.

To examine the thermal stability of these frameworks, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA; Fig. 5). Compound 1 was stable up to 380 °C; then, it shows a weight loss of about 82.8 % between 380 and 640 °C suggesting the decomposition of the organic framework, and the remaining weight is assigned to zinc oxide (17.2 %). Compound 2 shows an initial weight loss of 9 % below 101 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules; then, we have three steps of weight loss between 101 and 387 °C to obtain the final residue (15.2 %) which may be assigned to nickel oxide. Compound 3 was stable up to 328 °C then began to decompose upon further heating. The first continuous weight loss of 43 % happened in temperature range of 328–390 °C, and this weight loss can be attributed to the release of (1,10-phen) ligand; the second weight loss of 57 % between 390 and 489 °C was assigned to the release L ligand; the third weight loss of 43.6 % between 489 and 650 °C was of sulfate anions; and the remaining weight is assigned to cadmium oxide 13.4 %.

Magnetism

It is well known that the bis-bidentate oxalate ligands are particularly able to propagate electronic effects when the xy-type exchange pathway is operative [22, 23].

The large antiferromagnetic coupling often observed in oxalato-bridged compounds is due to the strong overlap between the xy-type magnetic orbitals centered on each metal ion and delocalized toward the oxygen atoms of the oxalato bridge [24]. Such a situation is found in copper(II) [25] and nickel(II) [26] binuclear species.

To investigate magnetic properties for 2, magnetic susceptibility was measured with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe from 2 to 300 K. Upon lowering the temperature, the χMT curve exhibits a gradual decrease to a minimum value of 0.05 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K. The continuous decrease in χMT value, along with the peak at 9 K in the χM-1\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M}^{ - 1} $$\end{document} plot, indicates antiferromagnetic interactions within Ni(II) ions.

To evaluate the antiferromagnetic interaction, we have simulated the magnetic susceptibility of 3 by using the spin Hamiltonian Ĥ = −2 JŜ1Ŝ2 + D(Ŝ1 + Ŝ2). The J value indicates that oxalate anion mediates a strong antiferromagnetic coupling between two nickel(II) ions separated by ca. 5.41 Å [23, 29]. The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K nicely follow the Curie–Weiss law (χMT = C/1 − θ), giving C = 5.44 cm3 K mol−1, θ = −166.4. The negative value of θ further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.

Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully constructed three new coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions using the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). Compound 1 is a one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting from extensive hydrogen bonds and compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and were also characterized by elemental analysis and IR spectra, and the thermal stability was also studied; furthermore, the magnetic measurements were carried out for compound 2 which shows strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.

All compounds were also characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis; furthermore, the magnetic measurements for 2 reveal antiferromagnetic coupling between the nickel(II) ions.the National Natural Science Foundation of China2146102321361023LiuJia-ChengLiuJia-Chengpublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count8issue-article-count12issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2016issue-copyright-holderSpringer International Publishing Switzerlandissue-copyright-year2016article-contains-esmYesarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2015article-registration-date-month11article-registration-date-day13article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11243_2015_Article_5.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2016issue-online-date-month2issue-online-date-day11issue-print-date-year2016issue-print-date-month2issue-print-date-day11issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryCatalysisjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionSC5open-accessfalseElectronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s11243-015-0005-4) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionMetal organic coordination networks have attracted a great deal of interest in recent years because of fundamental scientific interest and their potential applications in catalysis, absorption, magnetism and luminescence [1, 2]. The construction of MOFs mainly depends on the nature of the organic ligands (spacers) and metal ions (nodes) [3-5]. Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for a large diversity of topologies [6], but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures [7, 8]. On the other hand, the coordinating properties of N,N'-bis(coordinating group substituted) oxamides have been thoroughly investigated both in aqueous solution and in the solid state. The easy cis-trans isomerization equilibria that they exhibit together with the great variety of N,N'-substituents which can be used to play on the overall charge, complexing ability and polarity, make them very suitable ligands in designing homo- and heterometallic species [9-11]. Finally, one of the most appealing aspects of this type of ligands is the remarkable efficiency they exhibit to mediate strong antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers when acting as bridges [12, 13].In this regard, numerous substituents have been used to produce different kinds of oxamides, but to the best of our knowledge, we are the first to use 4-amino phthalic acid to synthesize such a ligand, namely oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). This ligand possess four carboxylic groups which can feature various coordination modes (Scheme 1) therefore leading to a variety of metal organic frameworks.In the present work, we report the synthesis of three coordination polymers by the use of different metal cations, oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid) and two auxiliary ligands: 2,2-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline. The 2,2-bipyridine chelates to metal ions through both of its nitrogen atoms and acts as a terminal or capping ligand. Therefore, hybrid structures containing 2,2-bipyridine are typically of lower dimensionalities [14], and as it is expected when using 2,2-bipyridine as an auxiliary ligand, we obtained two complexes with low dimensionalities [Zn(L)0.5(2,2'-bpy)]n(1) and [[Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-L⋅3H2O (2); complex 1 is one-dimensional while complex 2 is zero dimensional, but with the help of hydrogen bonds created by lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated ligand, a three-dimensional framework was built. 1,10-phenanthroline as an auxiliary ligand has strong chelating ability and good π-conjugated character because of the disposition of nitrogen atoms within the fused aromatic system which makes 1,10-phenanthroline a nearly universal ligand for d- and f-block metals [15-19]. Using 1,10-phenanthroline, complex 3 [Cd(L)(1,10-phen) which is three dimensional, was constructed.Experimental sectionGeneral physical measurementsX-ray crystallography data for 1-3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, O) were recorded on a VxRio EL Instrument. IR spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 range as KBr pellets on an FTS 3000 (US digilab) spectrometer (fig. S1-S4).Materials and general methodsChemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)(obpha) H4L was prepared in an analogous way to that reported for oxamide bis(2-benzoic) acid (H4obbz) [12] with slight modification (Scheme 2); 1.3 g (0.01 mol) of oxalyl chloride was added dropwise to a solution of 3.0 g (0.022 mol) of 4-aminophthalic acid in 50 mL of THF, and the mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 5 h. H4L precipitated as a white solid and was filtered off, washed with THF and dried. The yield was 75 %.Anal. Calcd for C18H12N2O10 (MW = 416) C, 51.9; H, 2.88; N, 6.73; O, 38.46. Found: C, 51.83; H, 2.84; N, 6.70; O, 38.37.IR (cm-1)3856 (w), 3746 (w), 3190 (s), 2984 (w), 2637 (w), 2550 (w), 1701 (s), 1582 (m), 1517 (s), 1407 (m), 1385 (m), 1300 (m), 1213 (m), 1136 (w), 1072 (w), 885 (w), 854 (w), 778 (w), 657 (w), 569 (w), 516 (w), 457 (w), 417 (w) fig (S1).Synthesis of complex [Zn2(L)(2,2'-bpy)2]n (1)A mixture of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (0.047 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 140 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature; colorless needle-like crystals of 1 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 70 %. IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3306 (w), 3061 (w), 1701 (s), 1605 (s), 1472 (m), 1433 (m), 1373 (s), 1154 (w), 1024 (w), 834 (w), 778 (m), 589 (w), 533 (w), 457 (w), 417 (w) fig (S2).Synthesis of complex [Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-L⋅3H2O (2)A mixture of NiSO4⋅7H2O (0; 056 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 110 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Violet block crystals of 2 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 63 %. IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3843 (w), 3741 (w), 3422 (s), 1642 (s), 1596 (w), 1506 (s), 1441 (w), 1351 (m), 1235 (w), 1153 (w), 1063 (w), 1024 (w), 925 (w), 826 (w), 770 (s), 417 (w) fig (S3).Synthesis of complex [Cd(L)(1,10-phen)] (3)A mixture of CdSO4⋅2H2O (0.049 g 0.2 mmol), L (042 g, 0.1 mmol), 1,10-phen (0.072 g, 0.4 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 130 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 3 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 55 %. IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3461 (s), 1636 (m), 1382 (w), 1114 (w), 1072 (w), 860 (w), 770 (w), 671 (w), 572 (w) fig (S4).X-ray crystallographyX-ray crystallography data for 1-3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are supplied in Tables 2 and 3.Results and discussionStructure description of 1X-ray structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P - 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of one half oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), one 2,2'-bpy ligand and one crystallographically unique Zn(II) ion. The Zn(II) center is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two H4L anions and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2-bpy ligand showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Fig. 1a). The average Zn-O and Zn-N distances are 2.46 and 2.064 Å, respectively. The Zn-O and Zn-N distances are quite similar to the normal Zn-O and Zn-N distances [20, 21]. The metal ions bind the oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups leaving the oxygens in the amido groups uncoordinated. Each H4L anion connects four Zn(II) cations and each two Zn(II) cations are connected by two H4L ligands to form a ladder-like one-dimensional chain with the metal ions and 2,2'-bpy at the edges of the chain (Fig. 1b). The 2,2'-bpy ligands and the H4L occupy two planes perpendicular to each other (Fig. 1c).Structure description of [Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-(L)⋅3H2O (2)X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P - 1(2), and the asymmetric unit consists of one H4L which is uncoordinated with the nickel ions, four units of 2,2'-bpy ligand, one oxalate anion, three lattice water molecules and two Ni(II) ions (Fig. 2b). The Ni(II) ions adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, and each Ni(II) is connected by two oxalato oxygen atoms from one µ2-oxalato anion and four nitrogen atoms from two 2,2'-bpy, one of which occupies the axial position and the other occupies the equatorial position.The architecture constructed by the Ni-bpy-oxalato moieties is extended through multiple hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional metal organic framework in which the molecules of water situated within the framework and stabilizing it by hydrogen-bonding interactions play a significant role beside the uncoordinated H4L ligand in connecting the different molecules of the complex (Fig. 2c); all water molecules are µ3-bonded: O10W-O1 = 2.77 Å, O10W-O7 = 11.01 Å, O10W-O8W = 10.44 Å, O8W-O5 = 3.302 Å, O8W-O9W = 2.843 Å, O9W-O4 = 2.802 Å, O9W-O3 = 2.791 Å; in addition to hydrogen bonds formed by water molecules, the molecular structure features intramolecular hydrogen bonds between O2 and O3, O2-O3 = 2.398 Å.It is worth noting that oxalate anions were formed as a result of amide bond cleavage in some H4L ligands, and these anions tend to connect two nickel ions (Ni-Ni = 5.41 Å) by chelating mode leading to construction of a binuclear cluster supported by four bpy ligands (Fig. 2a).Structure description of 3The X-ray structural determination indicates that complex 3 is a three-dimensional complex which crystallizes in monoclinic space group P 1 21/n 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of a Cd(II) ion, four oxygen atoms from three different H4L and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10 phenanthroline leading to an octahedral geometry around the central metal as illustrated in (Fig. 3a). The H4L anions show two types of coordination modes: the first anion has one bonding carboxylate group which is chelating bis-bidentate with a Cd-Cd distance of 15.432 Å and the other one connects four Cd(II) metal centers in a monodentate fashion which finally forms two-dimensional layers (Fig. 3b); these layers are connected by the bis-bidentate carboxylato groups to construct the three-dimensional layer (Fig. 3c).Extensive intramolecular hydrogen bonds were observed among the oxamido groups and the carboxylato groups within H4L ligand [N(2)-O(7) = 2.916 Å; N(1)-O(5) = 2.675 Å; N(1)-O(10) = 3.046 Å], also hydrogen bonds were observed between oxygens in carboxylato groups O(8)-O(9) = 2.445 Å; O(3)-O(1) = 2.364 Å; O(3)-O(9) = 3.024 Å.PXRD and thermogravimetric analysisPowder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out to check the purity of 1-3. The observed PXRD patterns are in good accordance with those simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. 4) and indicated the phase purity of the as-synthesized products.To examine the thermal stability of these frameworks, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA; Fig. 5). Compound 1 was stable up to 380 °C; then, it shows a weight loss of about 82.8 % between 380 and 640 °C suggesting the decomposition of the organic framework, and the remaining weight is assigned to zinc oxide (17.2 %). Compound 2 shows an initial weight loss of 9 % below 101 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules; then, we have three steps of weight loss between 101 and 387 °C to obtain the final residue (15.2 %) which may be assigned to nickel oxide. Compound 3 was stable up to 328 °C then began to decompose upon further heating. The first continuous weight loss of 43 % happened in temperature range of 328-390 °C, and this weight loss can be attributed to the release of (1,10-phen) ligand; the second weight loss of 57 % between 390 and 489 °C was assigned to the release L ligand; the third weight loss of 43.6 % between 489 and 650 °C was of sulfate anions; and the remaining weight is assigned to cadmium oxide 13.4 %.MagnetismIt is well known that the bis-bidentate oxalate ligands are particularly able to propagate electronic effects when the xy-type exchange pathway is operative [22, 23].The large antiferromagnetic coupling often observed in oxalato-bridged compounds is due to the strong overlap between the xy-type magnetic orbitals centered on each metal ion and delocalized toward the oxygen atoms of the oxalato bridge [24]. Such a situation is found in copper(II) [25] and nickel(II) [26] binuclear species.To investigate magnetic properties for 2, magnetic susceptibility was measured with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe from 2 to 300 K. The thermal dependence of χMT and χM-1\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M}^{ - 1} $$\end{document} is shown in (Fig. 6), the experimental χMT at 300 K of 3.5 cm3 mol-1 K is higher than that expected for two spin-only case of NiII ions (χMT = 2.0 cm3 K mol-1, S = 1), indicating an unquenched orbital contribution. Upon lowering the temperature, the χMT curve exhibits a gradual decrease to a minimum value of 0.05 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The continuous decrease in χMT value, along with the peak at 9 K in the χM-1\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M}^{ - 1} $$\end{document} plot, indicates antiferromagnetic interactions within Ni(II) ions.To evaluate the antiferromagnetic interaction, we have simulated the magnetic susceptibility of 3 by using the spin Hamiltonian Ĥ = -2 JŜ1Ŝ2 + D(Ŝ1 + Ŝ2). The resulting magnetic susceptibility is given by equation below [27, 28], where J is the intramolecular exchange integral, D is the zero-field splitting parameter, TIP represents the temperature independent paramagnetism and the other symbols have their usual meanings:χM=(2Ng2β2/kT)A/B+TIP\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M} = (2Ng^{2} \beta^{2} /kT)\left[ {A /B} \right] + {\text{TIP}} $$\end{document}whereA=4exp6J+2D)/kT+exp6J+D)/kT+exp[2J+D)/kTB=2exp6J+2D)/kT+2exp6J+D)/kT+exp3J+D9J22DJ+D21/2/kT+2exp(2J+D)/kT+exp2J+2D)/kT+exp3J+D+9J2-2DJ+D21/2/kT\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \begin{aligned} A &= 4\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] + \exp [\left( {2J + D) /kT} \right] \\  B  &= 2\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + 2\exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right)\left( {9J^{2} 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} + 2\exp \left[ {(2J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left[ {2J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right) + \left( {9J^{2} - 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} \\ \end{aligned} $$\end{document}The best fitting for the experiment data gives J = -17.35 cm-1, g = 2.22, D = -7.55 cm-1, TIP = 0.00469 cm3 mol-1 and the agreement factor R = 7.707 × 10-4. The J value indicates that oxalate anion mediates a strong antiferromagnetic coupling between two nickel(II) ions separated by ca. 5.41 Å [23, 29]. The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K nicely follow the Curie-Weiss law (χMT = C/1 - θ), giving C = 5.44 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -166.4. The negative value of θ further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions. ConclusionIn summary, we have successfully constructed three new coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions using the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). Compound 1 is a one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting from extensive hydrogen bonds and compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and were also characterized by elemental analysis and IR spectra, and the thermal stability was also studied; furthermore, the magnetic measurements were carried out for compound 2 which shows strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.Supplementary dataCCDC 1402642 to 1402644 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. Abstract

Three coordination polymers based on the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), namely [Zn(L)0.5-(2,2'-bpy)]n(1), [Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]L⋅3H2O (2) and [Cd(L)(1,10-phen)] (3) [L = oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)], (2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine), (1,10-phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction: compound 1 is one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting in extensive hydrogen bonds built with the help of lattice water molecules, compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds were also characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis; furthermore, the magnetic measurements for 2 reveal antiferromagnetic coupling between the nickel(II) ions.

Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for a large diversity of topologies [6], but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures [7, 8]. On the other hand, the coordinating properties of N,N′-bis(coordinating group substituted) oxamides have been thoroughly investigated both in aqueous solution and in the solid state. The easy cis–trans isomerization equilibria that they exhibit together with the great variety of N,N′-substituents which can be used to play on the overall charge, complexing ability and polarity, make them very suitable ligands in designing homo- and heterometallic species [9–11]. Finally, one of the most appealing aspects of this type of ligands is the remarkable efficiency they exhibit to mediate strong antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers when acting as bridges [12, 13].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal organic coordination networks have attracted a great deal of interest in recent years because of fundamental scientific interest and their potential applications in catalysis, absorption, magnetism and luminescence [1, 2]. The construction of MOFs mainly depends on the nature of the organic ligands (spacers) and metal ions (nodes) [3-5]. Among various organic ligands, multicarboxylate ligands are selected as multifunctional organic ligands, not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for a large diversity of topologies [6], but also because of their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures [7, 8]. On the other hand, the coordinating properties of N,N'-bis(coordinating group substituted) oxamides have been thoroughly investigated both in aqueous solution and in the solid state. The easy cis-trans isomerization equilibria that they exhibit together with the great variety of N,N'-substituents which can be used to play on the overall charge, complexing ability and polarity, make them very suitable ligands in designing homo- and heterometallic species [9-11]. Finally, one of the most appealing aspects of this type of ligands is the remarkable efficiency they exhibit to mediate strong antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers when acting as bridges [12, 13].

elements.content: In this regard, numerous substituents have been used to produce different kinds of oxamides, but to the best of our knowledge, we are the first to use 4-amino phthalic acid to synthesize such a ligand, namely oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). This ligand possess four carboxylic groups which can feature various coordination modes (Scheme 1) therefore leading to a variety of metal organic frameworks.

This ligand possess four carboxylic groups which can feature various coordination modes (Scheme 1) therefore leading to a variety of metal organic frameworks.

elements.content: In the present work, we report the synthesis of three coordination polymers by the use of different metal cations, oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid) and two auxiliary ligands: 2,2-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline. The 2,2-bipyridine chelates to metal ions through both of its nitrogen atoms and acts as a terminal or capping ligand. Therefore, hybrid structures containing 2,2-bipyridine are typically of lower dimensionalities [14], and as it is expected when using 2,2-bipyridine as an auxiliary ligand, we obtained two complexes with low dimensionalities [Zn(L)0.5(2,2′-bpy)]n(1) and [[Ni2(2,2′-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-L·3H2O (2); complex 1 is one-dimensional while complex 2 is zero dimensional, but with the help of hydrogen bonds created by lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated ligand, a three-dimensional framework was built. 1,10-phenanthroline as an auxiliary ligand has strong chelating ability and good π-conjugated character because of the disposition of nitrogen atoms within the fused aromatic system which makes 1,10-phenanthroline a nearly universal ligand for d- and f-block metals [15–19]. Using 1,10-phenanthroline, complex 3 [Cd(L)(1,10-phen) which is three dimensional, was constructed.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, we report the synthesis of three coordination polymers by the use of different metal cations, oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid) and two auxiliary ligands: 2,2-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline. The 2,2-bipyridine chelates to metal ions through both of its nitrogen atoms and acts as a terminal or capping ligand. Therefore, hybrid structures containing 2,2-bipyridine are typically of lower dimensionalities [14], and as it is expected when using 2,2-bipyridine as an auxiliary ligand, we obtained two complexes with low dimensionalities [Zn(L)0.5(2,2'-bpy)]n(1) and [[Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-L⋅3H2O (2); complex 1 is one-dimensional while complex 2 is zero dimensional, but with the help of hydrogen bonds created by lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated ligand, a three-dimensional framework was built. 1,10-phenanthroline as an auxiliary ligand has strong chelating ability and good π-conjugated character because of the disposition of nitrogen atoms within the fused aromatic system which makes 1,10-phenanthroline a nearly universal ligand for d- and f-block metals [15-19]. Using 1,10-phenanthroline, complex 3 [Cd(L)(1,10-phen) which is three dimensional, was constructed.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography data for 1–3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, O) were recorded on a VxRio EL Instrument. IR spectra were recorded in the 4000–400 cm−1 range as KBr pellets on an FTS 3000 (US digilab) spectrometer (fig. S1–S4).

Experimental section

General physical measurements

X-ray crystallography data for 1-3 were collected with an Agilent Technologies SuperNova CCD diffractometer with MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω scan mode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, O) were recorded on a VxRio EL Instrument. IR spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 range as KBr pellets on an FTS 3000 (US digilab) spectrometer (fig. S1-S4).

elements.content: Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)(obpha) H4L was prepared in an analogous way to that reported for oxamide bis(2-benzoic) acid (H4obbz) [12] with slight modification (Scheme 2); 1.3 g (0.01 mol) of oxalyl chloride was added dropwise to a solution of 3.0 g (0.022 mol) of 4-aminophthalic acid in 50 mL of THF, and the mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 5 h. H4L precipitated as a white solid and was filtered off, washed with THF and dried. The yield was 75 %.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and general methods

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid)(obpha) H4L was prepared in an analogous way to that reported for oxamide bis(2-benzoic) acid (H4obbz) [12] with slight modification (Scheme 2); 1.3 g (0.01 mol) of oxalyl chloride was added dropwise to a solution of 3.0 g (0.022 mol) of 4-aminophthalic acid in 50 mL of THF, and the mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 5 h. H4L precipitated as a white solid and was filtered off, washed with THF and dried. The yield was 75 %.

X-ray structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P – 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of one half oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), one 2,2′-bpy ligand and one crystallographically unique Zn(II) ion. The Zn(II) center is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two H4L anions and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2-bpy ligand showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Fig. 1a). The average Zn–O and Zn–N distances are 2.46 and 2.064 Å, respectively. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances are quite similar to the normal Zn–O and Zn–N distances [20, 21]. The metal ions bind the oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups leaving the oxygens in the amido groups uncoordinated. Each H4L anion connects four Zn(II) cations and each two Zn(II) cations are connected by two H4L ligands to form a ladder-like one-dimensional chain with the metal ions and 2,2′-bpy at the edges of the chain (Fig. 1b). The 2,2′-bpy ligands and the H4L occupy two planes perpendicular to each other (Fig. 1c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description of 1

X-ray structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P - 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of one half oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid), one 2,2'-bpy ligand and one crystallographically unique Zn(II) ion. The Zn(II) center is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two H4L anions and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2-bpy ligand showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Fig. 1a). The average Zn-O and Zn-N distances are 2.46 and 2.064 Å, respectively. The Zn-O and Zn-N distances are quite similar to the normal Zn-O and Zn-N distances [20, 21]. The metal ions bind the oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups leaving the oxygens in the amido groups uncoordinated. Each H4L anion connects four Zn(II) cations and each two Zn(II) cations are connected by two H4L ligands to form a ladder-like one-dimensional chain with the metal ions and 2,2'-bpy at the edges of the chain (Fig. 1b). The 2,2'-bpy ligands and the H4L occupy two planes perpendicular to each other (Fig. 1c).

elements.content: X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P − 1(2), and the asymmetric unit consists of one H4L which is uncoordinated with the nickel ions, four units of 2,2′-bpy ligand, one oxalate anion, three lattice water molecules and two Ni(II) ions (Fig. 2b). The Ni(II) ions adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, and each Ni(II) is connected by two oxalato oxygen atoms from one µ2-oxalato anion and four nitrogen atoms from two 2,2′-bpy, one of which occupies the axial position and the other occupies the equatorial position.
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of [Ni2(2,2'-bpy)4(µ2-Ox)]-(L)⋅3H2O (2)

X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P - 1(2), and the asymmetric unit consists of one H4L which is uncoordinated with the nickel ions, four units of 2,2'-bpy ligand, one oxalate anion, three lattice water molecules and two Ni(II) ions (Fig. 2b). The Ni(II) ions adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, and each Ni(II) is connected by two oxalato oxygen atoms from one µ2-oxalato anion and four nitrogen atoms from two 2,2'-bpy, one of which occupies the axial position and the other occupies the equatorial position.

elements.content: The architecture constructed by the Ni-bpy-oxalato moieties is extended through multiple hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional metal organic framework in which the molecules of water situated within the framework and stabilizing it by hydrogen-bonding interactions play a significant role beside the uncoordinated H4L ligand in connecting the different molecules of the complex (Fig. 2c); all water molecules are µ3-bonded: O10W–O1 = 2.77 Å, O10W–O7 = 11.01 Å, O10W–O8W = 10.44 Å, O8W–O5 = 3.302 Å, O8W–O9W = 2.843 Å, O9W–O4 = 2.802 Å, O9W–O3 = 2.791 Å; in addition to hydrogen bonds formed by water molecules, the molecular structure features intramolecular hydrogen bonds between O2 and O3, O2–O3 = 2.398 Å.

elements.content: It is worth noting that oxalate anions were formed as a result of amide bond cleavage in some H4L ligands, and these anions tend to connect two nickel ions (Ni–Ni = 5.41 Å) by chelating mode leading to construction of a binuclear cluster supported by four bpy ligands (Fig. 2a).

elements.content: The X-ray structural determination indicates that complex 3 is a three-dimensional complex which crystallizes in monoclinic space group P 1 21/n 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of a Cd(II) ion, four oxygen atoms from three different H4L and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10 phenanthroline leading to an octahedral geometry around the central metal as illustrated in (Fig. 3a). The H4L anions show two types of coordination modes: the first anion has one bonding carboxylate group which is chelating bis-bidentate with a Cd–Cd distance of 15.432 Å and the other one connects four Cd(II) metal centers in a monodentate fashion which finally forms two-dimensional layers (Fig. 3b); these layers are connected by the bis-bidentate carboxylato groups to construct the three-dimensional layer (Fig. 3c).
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 3

The X-ray structural determination indicates that complex 3 is a three-dimensional complex which crystallizes in monoclinic space group P 1 21/n 1, and the asymmetric unit consists of a Cd(II) ion, four oxygen atoms from three different H4L and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10 phenanthroline leading to an octahedral geometry around the central metal as illustrated in (Fig. 3a). The H4L anions show two types of coordination modes: the first anion has one bonding carboxylate group which is chelating bis-bidentate with a Cd-Cd distance of 15.432 Å and the other one connects four Cd(II) metal centers in a monodentate fashion which finally forms two-dimensional layers (Fig. 3b); these layers are connected by the bis-bidentate carboxylato groups to construct the three-dimensional layer (Fig. 3c).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out to check the purity of 1–3. The observed PXRD patterns are in good accordance with those simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. 4) and indicated the phase purity of the as-synthesized products.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out to check the purity of 1-3. The observed PXRD patterns are in good accordance with those simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. 4) and indicated the phase purity of the as-synthesized products.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stability of these frameworks, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA; Fig. 5). Compound 1 was stable up to 380 °C; then, it shows a weight loss of about 82.8 % between 380 and 640 °C suggesting the decomposition of the organic framework, and the remaining weight is assigned to zinc oxide (17.2 %). Compound 2 shows an initial weight loss of 9 % below 101 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules; then, we have three steps of weight loss between 101 and 387 °C to obtain the final residue (15.2 %) which may be assigned to nickel oxide. Compound 3 was stable up to 328 °C then began to decompose upon further heating. The first continuous weight loss of 43 % happened in temperature range of 328–390 °C, and this weight loss can be attributed to the release of (1,10-phen) ligand; the second weight loss of 57 % between 390 and 489 °C was assigned to the release L ligand; the third weight loss of 43.6 % between 489 and 650 °C was of sulfate anions; and the remaining weight is assigned to cadmium oxide 13.4 %.

elements.content:
It is well known that the bis-bidentate oxalate ligands are particularly able to propagate electronic effects when the xy-type exchange pathway is operative [22, 23].

The large antiferromagnetic coupling often observed in oxalato-bridged compounds is due to the strong overlap between the xy-type magnetic orbitals centered on each metal ion and delocalized toward the oxygen atoms of the oxalato bridge [24]. Such a situation is found in copper(II) [25] and nickel(II) [26] binuclear species.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetism

It is well known that the bis-bidentate oxalate ligands are particularly able to propagate electronic effects when the xy-type exchange pathway is operative [22, 23].

The large antiferromagnetic coupling often observed in oxalato-bridged compounds is due to the strong overlap between the xy-type magnetic orbitals centered on each metal ion and delocalized toward the oxygen atoms of the oxalato bridge [24]. Such a situation is found in copper(II) [25] and nickel(II) [26] binuclear species.

elements.content: To evaluate the antiferromagnetic interaction, we have simulated the magnetic susceptibility of 3 by using the spin Hamiltonian Ĥ = −2 JŜ1Ŝ2 + D(Ŝ1 + Ŝ2). The resulting magnetic susceptibility is given by equation below [27, 28], where J is the intramolecular exchange integral, D is the zero-field splitting parameter, TIP represents the temperature independent paramagnetism and the other symbols have their usual meanings:χM=(2Ng2β2/kT)A/B+TIP\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M} = (2Ng^{2} \beta^{2} /kT)\left[ {A /B} \right] + {\text{TIP}} $$\end{document}whereA=4exp6J+2D)/kT+exp6J+D)/kT+exp[2J+D)/kTB=2exp6J+2D)/kT+2exp6J+D)/kT+exp3J+D9J22DJ+D21/2/kT+2exp(2J+D)/kT+exp2J+2D)/kT+exp3J+D+9J2-2DJ+D21/2/kT\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \begin{aligned} A &= 4\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] + \exp [\left( {2J + D) /kT} \right] \\ B &= 2\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + 2\exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right)\left( {9J^{2} 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} + 2\exp \left[ {(2J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left[ {2J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right) + \left( {9J^{2} - 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} \\ \end{aligned} $$\end{document}The best fitting for the experiment data gives J = −17.35 cm−1, g = 2.22, D = −7.55 cm−1, TIP = 0.00469 cm3 mol−1 and the agreement factor R = 7.707 × 10−4. The J value indicates that oxalate anion mediates a strong antiferromagnetic coupling between two nickel(II) ions separated by ca. 5.41 Å [23, 29]. The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K nicely follow the Curie–Weiss law (χMT = C/1 − θ), giving C = 5.44 cm3 K mol−1, θ = −166.4. The negative value of θ further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.

The negative value of θ further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully constructed three new coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions using the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). Compound 1 is a one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting from extensive hydrogen bonds and compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and were also characterized by elemental analysis and IR spectra, and the thermal stability was also studied; furthermore, the magnetic measurements were carried out for compound 2 which shows strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully constructed three new coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions using the new ligand oxamide N,N-bis(4-phthalic acid). Compound 1 is a one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer, compound 2 exhibits a three-dimensional structure resulting from extensive hydrogen bonds and compound 3 also exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular structure. All compounds have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and were also characterized by elemental analysis and IR spectra, and the thermal stability was also studied; furthermore, the magnetic measurements were carried out for compound 2 which shows strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (0.047 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 140 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature; colorless needle-like crystals of 1 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 70 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3306 (w), 3061 (w), 1701 (s), 1605 (s), 1472 (m), 1433 (m), 1373 (s), 1154 (w), 1024 (w), 834 (w), 778 (m), 589 (w), 533 (w), 457 (w), 417 (w) fig (S2).

Synthesis of complex [Ni<sub>2</sub>(2,2′-bpy)<sub>4</sub>(<italic>µ</italic><sup>2</sup>-Ox)]-<italic>L</italic>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (2)

A mixture of NiSO4·7H2O (0; 056 g 0.2 mmol), L (0.083 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,2-bipyridene (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 110 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Violet block crystals of 2 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 63 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3843 (w), 3741 (w), 3422 (s), 1642 (s), 1596 (w), 1506 (s), 1441 (w), 1351 (m), 1235 (w), 1153 (w), 1063 (w), 1024 (w), 925 (w), 826 (w), 770 (s), 417 (w) fig (S3).

Synthesis of complex [Cd(<italic>L</italic>)(1,10-phen)] (3)

A mixture of CdSO4·2H2O (0.049 g 0.2 mmol), L (042 g, 0.1 mmol), 1,10-phen (0.072 g, 0.4 mmol) and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL), which was heated at 130 °C for 3 days and then gradually cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 3 were isolated from the mother liquid, washed with water, and then dried at ambient temperature. The yield was 55 %. IR/cm−1 (KBr): 3461 (s), 1636 (m), 1382 (w), 1114 (w), 1072 (w), 860 (w), 770 (w), 671 (w), 572 (w) fig (S4).

The resulting magnetic susceptibility is given by equation below [27, 28], where J is the intramolecular exchange integral, D is the zero-field splitting parameter, TIP represents the temperature independent paramagnetism and the other symbols have their usual meanings:χM=(2Ng2β2/kT)A/B+TIP\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \chi_{M} = (2Ng^{2} \beta^{2} /kT)\left[ {A /B} \right] + {\text{TIP}} $$\end{document}whereA=4exp6J+2D)/kT+exp6J+D)/kT+exp[2J+D)/kTB=2exp6J+2D)/kT+2exp6J+D)/kT+exp3J+D9J22DJ+D21/2/kT+2exp(2J+D)/kT+exp2J+2D)/kT+exp3J+D+9J2-2DJ+D21/2/kT\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \begin{aligned} A &= 4\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] + \exp [\left( {2J + D) /kT} \right] \\ B &= 2\exp \left[ {\left( {6J + 2D) /kT} \right] + 2\exp } \right[\left( {6J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right)\left( {9J^{2} 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} + 2\exp \left[ {(2J + D) /kT} \right] \\ &\quad + \exp \left[ {2J + 2D) /kT} \right] + \exp \left\{ {\left[ {\left( {3J + D} \right) + \left( {9J^{2} - 2DJ + D^{2} } \right)^{1/2} } \right] /kT} \right\} \\ \end{aligned} $$\end{document}The best fitting for the experiment data gives J = −17.35 cm−1, g = 2.22, D = −7.55 cm−1, TIP = 0.00469 cm3 mol−1 and the agreement factor R = 7.707 × 10−4. The J value indicates that oxalate anion mediates a strong antiferromagnetic coupling between two nickel(II) ions separated by ca. 5.41 Å [23, 29]. The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K nicely follow the Curie–Weiss law (χMT = C/1 − θ), giving C = 5.44 cm3 K mol−1, θ = −166.4. The negative value of θ further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between Ni(II) ions.
